name: jstegall
text: The halls of American musical history reside within the walls of the Sony label apparently.

name: troy_convers
text: 'cept for Elvis who was on the RCA label...

name: projectyl
text: I'm a little rusty at sight-reading music, but I'm about 75% sure Ray's busting out the first bar of The Entertainer there in the first panel.

name: dzieger
text: Quite correct -- but I can't identify the piece in the previous strip. I played it, and it's legit, but doesn't  ring a bell.

name: asherdan
text: A comment left by asherdan was marked lame too many times and excluded. (marked lame by apocowarg, ActualTaunt, gbeaton, jmmfgd)

name: unquotable
text: A comment left by unquotable was marked lame too many times and excluded. (marked lame by scraggg, VictoriaW, Satyr)

name: mattylite
text: Someone said it was Elite Syncopations, and they were right.  It was Elite Syncopations.

name: thesoulbear
text:
Scott Joplin is so good
He is the goodest at ragtime

name: chopper
text: Also, obvious Neil Young reference...Anyone know if he or any of his bands are/were on Sony?

name: ssddr
text: The Entertainer?

name: rotating-dog
text: A little part of it in everyone.

name: sp1derbaby
text: Chubbied for getting there first.

name: i_love_kate
text: It is only a strip such as Achewood in which the same comic which has the second panel in this one could also have the fourth panel.

name: reverendsam
text: a low rating? a handful of boring comments? ladies and gentlemen ray just got rich have some respect

name: binlaggin
text: voted 5 for classic alt text

name: fancyrat
text: Same. It sort of sums up all of Achewood.

name: beansdooma
text: a cat in a thong is getting a record offer

name: rowboat
text: I gave it a middling rating. Now here's my boring comment.

name: donnatron
text: Ray never reads the enclosed contract.

name: tekende
text: Apparently Sony stopped updating their list of American musical legends sometime in the 1960s.

name: mercuri0us
text: name some American musical legends since the 1960s.  Hendrix should be there.

name: lightupafatty
text:
david byrne. kurt cobain. joey ramone. bruce springsteen.
probably more.

name: bpmead
text: Sorry to say the obvious but Bob Dylan anyone?

name: fineoakstructure
text: Bob Dylan, though still going strong, has practically become the 60's in the American consciousness. Try again.

name: tekende
text:
David Bowie. Ian Curtis. Tori Amos. Billy Joel (maybe). Just off the top of my head.

Hendrix is overrated.

name: tekende
text: Oh wait American. Cross off those first two, then.

name: fineoakstructure
text:
Billy Joel might stay around in the popular mind for a while, but I don't think he's going to ever be considered a musical legend, and, damn, I don't care if you like her or not, but Tori Amos? C'mon.

(You gotta thing for corny piano players, tekende?)

wait i sound like belgand here don't i

name: tekende
text: I have a thing for Tori Amos.

name: rowboat
text: That in itself is not a bad thing. "Hendrix is overrated" is a bad thing.

name: rowboat
text:
And oh yeah, the original discussion up there:

Merle Haggard, John Coltrane, Tom Waits, Lou Reed, RZA, Gram Parsons.

name: tekende
text:
There you go, that is a good list.

And I'm sorry, but I don't think Hendrix is that good. He was a sloppy guitarist (occasionally that worked in his favor; his rendition of the national anthem is my favorite) and his singing sounded like he was trying to be Bob Dylan. Basically other than the national anthem and "All Along the Watchtower" (which is a Dylan song anyway) I don't really like his music at all.

name: mercuri0us
text: He was innovative.  He did things no-one else had ever done before, and which forever changed the sound of rock music.  There is probably not a rock or metal band since that was not influenced by him to some degree.  That's what makes him a legend.

name: theguitarhero
text: and with that, mercuri0us spat upon tekende for his controversial ideas on the history of rock and roll.
